comments.text: How do you use it?
comments.author: Ronn2664

comments.text: It lets u see as it's printing if you have areas that are too thin or not sticking so u know which area of your bed to adjust. It's it's really thin line or non existent layer, then your nozzle is too close to the bed and u need to lower that quadrant of the print bed. If it's not sticking or the layer is really round u probably have too much space between the nozzle and the bed so you need to raise the bed a bit.

A Raspberry Pi Zero case specially designed for the Pimoroni Unicorn pHAT. The Raspberry Pi Zero ports are fully accessible and the top snaps securely to the bottom. The cover uses .2m of plastic almost directly on top of the LEDs to give a bright but every so slightly diffused look. I recommend either white or clear to allow full color spectrum.

Print the top, bottom, and support pins. Assemble by pressing the Raspberry PI (Carefully!) into the bottom of the case. Add the support pins and install the Unicorn pHAT.

When installing the top, realize the clips are not centered. Because of the geometry of the Raspberry Pi Zero, the clips are slight offset to the MicroSD card. Make sure you put the top on in the correct direction!

Once the top is installed, it is difficult to take apart without breaking the clips on the case. If you do need to remove the cover, press on the side with the microUSB/HDMI adapters to release that clip first. Then gently the opposite side free. A small screwdriver is handy.

print_settings.Notes:: Enjoy, resize to your liking, and comment any suggestions.

comments.text: Fkrezel,
comments.author: Fkrezel

comments.text: If you had to do it all over again and it was your first quad what would you have printed? Scale? Type? Etc?  Trying to get into the hobby but am finding alot of types and not sure which to do. I don't see myself as a racer with FPV, I'm more of a cruise around and admire from the air.
comments.author: kalderis10

comments.text: I didn't design this to be a racer. It's a gentle flier and is stable once the flight controller it set up. I wanted something that could just cruise around slowly and take gentle video. The flight controller is able to be set up for agile flight, but I prefer the gentle flight. I have a race quad and I find myself flying this more. This quad is big enough to fight some wind and not get blown around. If you are wanting to get something ready to fly and don't want to spend a lot, I bought a Hubsan S501 from Amazon. It's an easy to fly quad. Has a good camera, and has on-board video transmission so you can see what the camera is seeing. If you have never flown a quad before, this might be something to look into first, then build one. You will have a better understanding of quads. I would definitely only do a quad, nothing more like a hex or a tri copter for my first UAV. With all that said, being a new pilot (presumably) I would probably buy one first. DJI makes an excellent product. I started off with a Phantom 3 Advanced. This was my first quad. It was super easy to fly. The DJI Spark is a good option to get into the hobby with. The reasy I mentioned the Hubsan S501 is due to the cost. You can get the HUbsan for under $300 on Amazon. I don't want to discourage you from printing your own, I want to you enjoy the hobby :) I hope this helps. Feel free to respond with more questions if you need.

remixed_from.author: rswarner
remixed_from.title: Internal filament guide for Printrbot direct drive extruder

title: Printrbot Simple Direct Drive Bowden conversion

description.text: Improved version at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:305215 Parts to convert a PrintrBot Simple with a direct drive extruder (not aluminium) to make use of a Bowden tube. No changes to the Simple itself are required (no new holes etc.). Motor and extruder are mounted on the Z axis support bars. All parts are sized to be printable with a Simple. UPDATE v2: Redesign of extruder and extruder model support so that the extruder unit can rotate as required to alleviate pressure on the bowden tube as it bends. This has allowed the tube to be less than a foot long. Extruder fitting is an adaptation of the Internal filament guide for Printrbot direct drive extruder by rswarner. The Hotend fitting is an adaptation of one of the fittings in Printrbot Simple Bowden conversion by owens to make it fit the new extruder location.

Print 1 of each component, apart from the flat disks where 2 are needed. The hotend block screws into existing holes at the end of the Simple Y axis arm and the hotend mounts using the existing screws. New screws are needed to attach the block. The printed fan mount fits using one of the screws used to attach the hotend block. The extruder fitting replaces the hollow plastic tube and the small wooden component in the extruder assembly. The push fits screw into the hotend block and the extruder fitting. The new extruder support fitting requires printing 2x flat disks and 1 support. The disks go either side of the support aligned with the hole and the extruder assembly is screwed to the motor through the disks. This allows the assembly to rotate as the Y axis arm raises and moves. The hole through the hotend block corner is to allow the cables to be cable wrapped as per the normal setup. There is also an extra screw hole in the block to allow the hotend to be firmed up if it isnt firm initially (i havent needed this, so skip if it works ok for you). Additional components: 2x 25mm (or longer) M3 bolts with nuts will be required to attach the hotend component. PTFE tube (4mm outer, 2mm inner) and push fittings needed to attach the tube to the fittings (self threading). The push fittings i sized it for can be found at http://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/B00H53FYHE/

Betafite is a popular uranium bearing mineral to collect. It is one of the few uranium minerals to form nice well shaped crystals. Betafite crystallizes in the isometric symmetry class and forms large octahedral and dodecahedral crystals that can weigh up to 100 kg. Frequently they are modified by other isometric forms and/or flattened when two opposing faces dominate the crystal. Well formed crystals of betafite are considered classics!

author: MudRaker

description.text:
I saw this (quite old) challenge online:
https://www.makerbot.com/media-center/2011/10/11/openscad-challenge-klein-bottle

I could not resist making my own! I'm perfectionist, I made it as perfect as I could.

I made it using bezier curves because that was a lot easier than trying to model the shape by removing "donnut" shapes around it (I could not see a neat solution to do this). Since there is no bezier functionality in OpenSCAD, I had to create my own, from an existing library found on thingiverse.

The bottle is easy to customise. I added 4 variables at the beginning of the files:

  • wallThickness
  • bottleHeight
  • bottleDiameter
  • tubeDiameter

The "precision" (number of polygons generated) is also configurable. I set it to 180 to generate the STL files. I might have exaggerated, the STL files are quite large!

I also uploaded a "cut" version to see inside the bottle. That one is for education purpose, and also to prove that I didn't "cheated".

Bezier library: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2170645

NOTE: The library is quite small, I uploaded it with the model for simplicity.

[2017-03-13] This model doesn't print well. I need to adjust the wall thickness and flatten the bottom. I will upload a version 2 very soon.

[2017-03-14] Uploaded v2 - Updated version of the library bezier.scad, thicker walls and flat bottom. The bottle body is now entirely made with bezier. I also fixed the "2-manifold" warning which was due to floating point noise. If you prefer the round bottom (as it was before), you can edit the file klein-bottle_v2.scad and change bottleBezier(true); to bottleBezier(false); in module bottle(). Hopefully it will be easier to print with these adjustments.

[2017-03-18] Today, I started experimenting with Slic3r. I discovered that my "floating point" correction was good to get rid of OpenSCAD warning, but made my STL unusable in Slic3r. I tried to use to "Fix STL file" function in Slic3r but it made it worse. I re-generated my version 2 without the floating point correction, and now it works nicely in Slic3r. Having a warning in OpenSCAD is better than having a STL file that can't be printed.

NOTE: Use version 2 for printing. The walls of the other version are too thin, the bottle is not waterproof.

I never printed it; I'm still waiting for my Prusa i3 MK2 printer. I'm very new with 3D printing and 3D modelling in general. Comments and suggestions are very welcomed.

[FIXED] When OpenSCAD render it for STL export, it complains that the object might need repair. I'm not sure what that means, I could not find information about how to fix this (if that even needs to be fixed). I will upload a fixed version if that causes any issues.
Object may not be a valid 2-manifold and may need repair!
NOTE: The warning was due to the faces of 2 shapes mathematically touching, but not quite touching due to floating point imprecision (noise). I fixed the issue by increasing the length of the object by a very small amount, just enough to cover the floating point noise without altering the look of the shape.
NOTE2: The fix introduced issues that make the STL file unprintable with Slic3r (and probably most slicer programs). I reverted it to the mathematical solution, ignoring the warning in OpenSCAD.

According to those who printed it, no supports are required.

If you print it, I would love to know how it went.

comments.text:
This requires a "Development snapshot" of openscad to render. Not their normal one. scroll down on the page

title: Aligning jig for spot welding two 18650 Lithium cells in parallel

description.text:
I had already designed an aligning tool which worked but it was not very practical in use, so I made this new version:

When paralleling 18650 Lithium ion cells by spot welding, it is often challenging to get the nickel strips straight and to precisely hit the poles with the spot welder, especially the smaller plus poles.

This aligning tool is for paralleling two 18650 cells with 7mm wide nickel strip.

How to use:

Insert the batteries and nickel strip into the adapter, plus poles on the side with the smaller opening, minus poles at the larger one. There are two slots for using rubber bands to hold the cells at the bottom if necessary. Spot weld through the openings, then remove your paralleled pack from the jig. The openings at the bottom can be used for pushing them out.

IMPORTANT NOTE: Before you start, be sure to measure the voltage on both batteries, there should be no more than 0.1V difference in voltage. Charge/discharge them to reach the same voltage before connecting them in parallel.

This is an OpenSCAD library to generate pixelly fonts, mostly based on some PalmOS bitmap fonts from Ron Buelow. There are 29 fonts included.

I used it to make a Minecraft-themed text topper for a birthday cake. The full library code is here -- the downloads for this Thing just include a self-contained demo file.

To use, start with:
include <pixellyfont.scad>
The syntax for the main library call, with defaults indicated, is:
renderString(string,font=font_8x8,halign="left",valign="bottom",invert=false,spacing=1,size=10,pixelScale=1.01,height=0)

string: text to render; only characters included in the CP-1252 character set are supported; other characters will be turned to spaces
font: font to use; the fonts are defined in fontdata.scad
halign: horizontal alignment: "left", "right" or "center"
valign: vertical alignment: "bottom", "top" or "center"
invert: set to true if you want to draw the background instead of the characters
spacing: scale for character spacing
size: height of characters
pixelScale: the scaling to apply to the pixels; if you increase it noticeably above 1, the pixels will join up more, and if you decrease it below 1, you'll get blank space around them
height height to extrude pixels; set to 0 to make pixels 2D

You can also use renderString() as a modifier for a shape. In that case, pixelScale and height are ignored, and instead the shape is used as a pixel. For instance, you can do this to make foreground pixels be large circles and background pixels be small circles:
renderString("abc") circle(d=1);
renderString("abc",invert=true) circle(d=0.1);

If you want to know how much horizontal space text will take up, you can call
getStringWidth(string[,options]) where the available options are the font, spacing and size options that renderString() uses.

If you want to know how many pixels high characters in a font are, call getFontHeight(font). You can then compute the size of an individual pixel as size/getFontHeight(font) where size is the size parameter for renderString().

title: MicroSD and SD card Holders (and Generic Containers)

description.text:
This is a rebuild/remix of the Micro SD Card Holder from bgill.

I basically gutted his uSD card slots as they seemed a bit too tight. I also slightly enlarged the cap threads and added a mild taper to the cap threads to make the cap easier to thread on if there are any irregularities in the print.

I provided a 16x uSD card model and a larger model that holds 6x SD cards and 2x uSD cards. Both uSD and SD holder bottoms expect the standard cap. If you use the large cap, the cards will rattle around needlessly. The extra large cap will allow the uSD cards to fall out of their slots.

In addition, I created generic open containers with both flat and rounded bottoms and two extended caps for general use holding screws or whatever loose stuff you got laying around. The rounded bottom ones make getting small items out easier. There are 3 depths of bottoms, standard, large and extra large. There are also 3 sizes of caps, standard, large and extra large.

The caps are shown and modeled right side up, you should 180 them so the top of the cap is against your print bed for printing (hollow facing upwards).

Note: I have also included a solid bottom piece that you can easily boolean out of to make whatever specific container you need.

description.text:
This farm playset is meant for your toddler starting from the age of about 2 years. Be careful to glue all pieces together so nothing gets loose for those little toddler's mouths!

The farm is meant to be printable without any supports and all pieces can be printed separately so you can print them each in their corresponding color and so you don't have to paint anything (or at least not a lot) afterwards. However I always provide the fully assembled piece as well to be printed a single color!

The Fence

For the fence you just need to print the assembled fence (I recommend with supports or you will have a little hang on the fence bars) or the parts separately. Then you would need to print the fence-bar and the post of the fence both twice.
Things to print:

  • 2 x Fence bar
  • 2 x Post of the fence

The Tree (Apple Tree)

Again, for the apple tree you could print all at once or the pieces separate. Only thing that is always separate are the apples.
The trunk and the crown of the three needs to be attached together with one 24mm plug.
Things to print:

  • 1 x Tree Trunk
  • 1 x Tree Crown (with or without apples)
  • 1 x 24mm plug
  • 1 x Set of apples (if you printed the apple crown)

A Sheep

For the sheep you will need the 12mm plug to plug the head and the body together. The legs of the sheep don't need a plug (however some glue is advised with kids). They fit really tight so it's better to plug in the legs before the head so you have some grip to give it the needed pressure to get them in.
Things to print:

  • 1 x Sheep Body
  • 1 x Sheep Head
  • 2 x Sheep Legs
  • 1 x 12mm Plug

A Pig

For the pig you will need the 12mm plug to plug the head and the body together. The legs of the pig don't need a plug (however some glue is advised with kids). They fit really tight so it's better to plug in the legs before the head so you have some grip to give it the needed pressure to get them in.
Things to print:

  • 1 x Pig Body
  • 1 x Pig Head
  • 2 x Pig Legs
  • 1 x 12mm Plug

A Cow

Soon to come...

A Chicken

Soon to come...

All of the pieces (as they are on the photo's) are printed with an infill of just 20%, also the plugs. The stronger you want the toys to be, the more infill you should print with!

title: e-bike display adapter for basket mounting bracket

description.text:
This adapter was designed to allow an e-bike display to be securely mounted as part of the bike basket bracket. My e-bike handle bars áre not wide enough to use two separate mounting brackets.

This was specifically designed for use with the display on the Onya F19 e-bike (onya.co.nz) and pack and Pedal bike basket.

The finished print in the photos needed some cleaning up., sanding and treated with acetone. this is the improved version, with the screws on the back of the display a little easier to get to.

author: Fraslagu

title: Heavy Duty Planet Gear
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a reduction box I designed and made with a 8mm output shaft to suit my application (using 2 off these for my belt driven Z axis) . I've included the drawing files feel free to alter as needed. Please not some of the bearing holes have been altered in these files to suit my printer and filament. All these parts are printed in PLA but have also made and have been running 2 of these for about 6 months now in ABS.Everything was printed from my computer using Simplify3D with a 3mm nozzle and 0.15 layer height with 20% infill and 5 outter shells in all directions, Sun gear is 15 teeth, Planet gears are 25 teeth and ring gear is 60 teeth. If I have worked it out right its a 5:1 ratio.
Enjoy

Printer:

My Own

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%
Just the normal light cleanup and lube with a good grease.

Print
1 Cover
3 Planet Gears
1 Planet Retainer
1 Ring Gear
1 Sun Gear

Bearings

4off 608zz Bearings [3 planet gear 1output shaft]
3off 624zz Bearings [3 planet gear]
1off 105zz Bearing [sun gear]

Nuts n Bolts
3off m4 60 cap screws with nylex nuts (cut bolts to 44mm) [Planet gear retainer]
4off m3 grub screws 3mm long min [1 for sun gear 3 for drive shaft]
8off m3 10 cap screws with nylex nuts [for joining body]
4off m3 8 cap screws [ring gear to nema]
4off m3 ? cap screws with nylex nuts [cover to machine mount length to suit]
1off 8mm washer {between planet retainer and body]

Shaft
8mm * ? drive shaft turn down one end to 5mm to incert into 105zz bearing

title: Keychain with Belarusian ornament "Spring"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
The drawing on this keychain is a folk Belarusian ornament that was used in needlework (embroidery on clothes) and denotes a wonderful time of the year "spring".
The upper side of the ornament should be painted in red for complete authenticity.

ATTENTION!!! This thing is big (it was convenient to do the design), so do the scaling to the size you need.

scaling up alone won't do as you said, but by also decreasing wall thickness all should fit into the box.
comments.author: Kit_Raevson

I used Sketchup.

You could try to skale it a bit. I got 1 cm left in my box maybe it is enough.
comments.author: walktime

comments.text:
scaling up to box size won't help, big cards with FFG sleeves are 93mm long, but there should be at least 1mm space extra to put them in, which is 94x3 = 282mm and there is 286mm space, that is 4mm for 4 walls. i'd probably make ~0.45-0.5mm (1 extrusion line) two inner walls each and 1.5mm for each outer walls on the sides. no need to change front and back.
also small cards are 67mm long so at least 68-69mm space would be required which could probably be achieved in simmilar fashion.
comments.author: Kit_Raevson

comments.text: Thank you!  That should be perfect.
comments.author: BigG2016

comments.text: Since I had a PLA print droop in the heat outside one time, I decided to print this cardholder in ABS.  It turned out quite well at .2mm except for the small piece on the short side where the snap loop slides through.  That small piece did not print well and easily popped off.  However, with some special plastic glue and some tiny trimmed pull ties, I managed to add the loop back on it.  My only recommendation for a tweak would be to increase the thickness/girth of the small side piece where the snap loop connects.  That bit of reinforcement should do the trick.  Thank you.
comments.author: BigG2016

comments.text: Thanks! The model has been updated. I hope you like it.
comments.author: BigG2016

description.text:
This is a simple yet fun bag clip or paperclip than can be used to clip any bag closed or paperwork together.
Designed by me in OpenSCAD, it is ment to hold sheets op paper. plastic together or to close open bags in the kitchen or office.

The long edge of the clip is there to make it easier to set it to the edge of the items you want to clip together.
The semi-dish on top is to facilitate an easy push and comfortable push of the clip.
Or, for removing, a good hold to remove the clip.
The circular opening on top of the clip is to keep the rolled up part of any bag that you use the clip on.

I have uploaded three versions of this clip, each with a different height.
One is 7mm, the second 10mm and the third is 14mm high.
The wider clips work well on plastic bags. The 7mm model works fine on paperwork.

Printer:

Mankati Fullscale XT/XT-Plus

Rafts:

No

Resolution:

0.1-0.2mm

Notes:

Printing this is easy.
Print it in PLA, PETG or ABS or any material of you choosing.

Give it a good shell and decent infill to make sure the clip will be strong enough.

description.text:
A bracket to hold a NEMA17 stepper motor on a 20mm V-slot or T-slot extrusion like 2020 or 2040.

I've done a test print and it works as intended. Use M4x10 or M4x12 screws with the usual slot nuts. Add a washer under the screw cap if you'd like to spread the load a little more.

OpenSCAD source is included if you'd like to modify the design. The design is almost all calculated from variables so should be easy to hack for different motors/extrusions. You could even make it parametric with a little effort.

This is the first 3D design I've ever done. I'm interested in receiving comments or constructive criticism on anything I've done.

description.text:
Get you anti zombification meds neatly organized with this pill dispenser.
It has 7 chambers and one blank to close it.
Made this for my girlfriend when she had to take meds on a daily basis and hated the big boxes form the hospital.
She is a big fan of the Resident Evil games so I surprised her with this.

Print the bottom in white.
The top in black
and 4 of the covers in red and 3 in white.
Glue the covers onto the top piece as shown in the pictures and use a screw to attach it to the bottom (one from a servo works nicely cause of the smooth shaft at the end of the screw)
Don't tighten it to much or you won't be able to rotate it properly.

comments.text: I kid you not, I was browsing through pill boxes looking for something to store my week's vitamins in and found nothing I really liked.  So I saved a few that I thought were passable and then went looking for RE stuff.  You have no idea how excited I was to find this!  I can't wait to print it out.  Thanks man!
comments.author: basementvaultdweller

description.text: C EST UNE COQUE

This is the initial design for a quick release mechanism that will fit on a printer like the Robo3D to mount an E3D V6, using the Nimble extruder.
The quick release mechanism makes it easy to quickly mount and un-mount the hot end by using a rotating wedge to clamp the Nimble base plate against the back wedge.
The wedge is shaped in such a way that it locks the base plate in 2 directions.

Edit: The Cam Clamp and the Nimble Mount plate are now adjusted and will fit perfectly on the Robo3D X carriage as designed by lurkinturtle. (excellent work by the way!)

Robo3D R1 Full carriage

The Back Wedge plate, needs to 3 mm holes to be drilled in the X Carriage. The front Cam Clamp can be bolted using the existing 4 mm hole.

The Nimble Extruder

The Nimble Extruder

With an installed weight of less than 27 grams on your carriage/effector the Zesty Nimble is smallest and lightest extruder you can buy, it has ample torque and can be mounted in multiple orientations.

The Nimble is available from Zesty Technology.

description.text:
This is a fully working 3D printed watch based on the Casio F91W.

The glass piece is 27mm diameter and 2mm thick and is friction fit in the body.

Bear in mind that your results may vary as every printer and filament will give different tolerances.

The body was printed in Fillamentum's Timbertfill filament and the strap in FFFworld's FlexiSmart filament.

Best printed with 1mm walls on both the body and strap (pictured are 2mm walls which ended up separating on the strap).

Good luck!

title: A case for Apple earbud container covers

description.text:
I really didn't like that Apple earbud boxes were unusable. The mouldings to hold the buds are not removable.
So I designed a base to match the old covers, voila - I present: box with clear lid.

The design has a 1.6mm wall, 1mm deep lip with a 0.8mm ledge. Printed with the Flexion (although a stock print-head should be the same) in PLA at 0.2mm layer height.

Just designed in Sketchup. Experiment a bit if you need to, if the lid doesn't quite fit, scale it by 0.1 up or down.

title: Holder for Drawdio Board
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A laser cut board to make it removing and adding a drawdio board to multiple devices. Zip-tie the holder to paintbrushes, pencils, etc. instead of the drawdio board. I created this board for a week long lesson titled "Scientific Inquiry Using Electricity" for students in grades 3-6 with the learning objective of teaching students how to write questions while making scientific observations, and then use the data collected to answer the questions written. This holder was made to hold the Drawdio board sold by adafruit.com
http://www.adafruit.com/products/197. The Lesson could be easily work with a cheaper 555-timer based noise maker - http://www.instructables.com/id/Building-a-Noise-Maker-with-Bare-Paint-and-a-555-t/ A complete week-long MN Science stanards aligned lesson for grades 3-6 that uses the board can be found at https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PkOOTJgug72I07byVQfwB4c56I5cynhe_Q7FwXfffaY/edit?usp=sharing Introduction and instructional videos are found in the following presentation:
https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1FfMQhN6KnziJrQaF6fjkNtL6Msj63dgdaEXNuqBzAO4/edit?usp=sharing 2-page handout for a drawdio workshop I taught to kids. http://sciencearium.com/wp-content/uploads/2012/11/Drawdio-Experiments.pdf

Laser cut from 1/4" plywood.  Zip-tie the holder to your drawing tool (paint brush, pencil, etc.).  Use T-nuts, machine screws, and paperclips to attach drawdio board to the holder.  
Wrap copper tape around your drawing tool so that it makes electrical connections with the holder via the T-nut or to the top paperclips.

title: another Leapfrog Creatr enclosure with Wifi Cam and side plates openers

description.text:
Hi

This is a Leapfrog Creatr enclosure with Wifi Cam and side plates openers

https://youtu.be/xDyH5j41lJM

The walls are from 5mm clear acrylic (with few more holes for flexibility)
All the screws except the rail screws are M4 with M4 Nuts and plastic washers (with few lengthens and screw heads)

The rail screws are M8 Nut with their heads grind to fit in the rails (https://youtu.be/SmlmNkBJR4A )

The printed part are from ABS

Self holding acrylic hinge

I have printed the upper hinges in the connected form (but two parts STL files are also included)
https://youtu.be/MmahfyKiX-0

There is a back holder for the enclosure but I haven’t used it in the end

The acrylic part under the upper door has two functions :

  1. To serve as a rest for the upper door
  2. It close the narrow gape between the upper door and the upper cover and preventing the filament from stuck in it

https://youtu.be/Vwrk2PtWI3s

Keep in mind that under this acrylic rest there is a shorter corner (to offset for the 5 mm of the part ) corner inner -5mm .STL

The door handle is connected to the door with an Iron screw and there is a Magnet holder that hold the door in place with a 6.2 mm X 6.2mm diameter NEODYMIUM MAGNET

Side plates openers
For a long time I am using the side plates opener from Ghost3D (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:307931 )and they are very handy for maintenance and for removing printed parts from the print bad

https://youtu.be/QjYq-rN7A3s

I have designed a slider lock that from one end holed the acrylic enclose and from the other hand as a slider that lock and unlock the side plates in place

Wifi Camera
The Wifi camera is the DX SKU 449864 (http://www.dx.com/p/suneyes-sp-v701w-720p-hd-mini-wireless-outdoor-ip-camera-eu-plug-449864#.WMU2rW996Uk)

The M12 lens was replaced for a wider angle lens (from ~65 degrees to ~120 degrees)

And a new smaller enclosure Based on Gilad's mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:267313) with new holder and a rail mount to holed the camera in the printer and the antenna outside of the printer

Sorry for the spelling mistakes

author: thedemri

description.text:
This is a modified version of the extruder unit of Prusa i3 MK2 to fit most other printers out there.

This is to accommodate mk8 extruder unit with filament guide, has 2 version for each except extruder cover; shorter can use either 18-20mm m3 screws just like normal and normal version are based on the prusa mk2's screw sets. More details below.

This is actually a great compact extruder mount and unit to begin with.

These are meant to be used on the MK2's carriage included as well.
I included the source file for you guys to fiddle with this base and customise them further.

Credit to Prusa's team for these designs

Update

24th September 2017

  • Added Y-splitter D6

8th September 2017

  • Added Multi Material for BLTouch

12 August 2017

  • Added Multi Material series

11th April 2017

  • Added Bowden series
MM Parts and Y-Splitter

I added the new MM parts just like the MK2S parts previously and can be used as either bowden or multi material which will be paired with the y-splitter.stl from prusa3d. I did not take any credits for any of the original designs as I only modified these designs to cater conventional inductive probe sizes.

Any cheap chinese e3d v6 style should be able to fit into these parts but if you're going to pair them up with the y-splitter, you can't use them with the pneumatic fittings. I myself forgot to measure the length of the teflon tube that is inside the y-splitter and the hotend itself.

Estimated length of the protruding teflon tube should be about 10-15mm more than the hotend's aluminum body.

The y-splitter however aren't modified yet so you might be having trouble on how to fit in the pneumatic fittings on the y-splitter itself

While I am working slowly on the prusa3d y-splitter, can use the bowden series paired with this https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2111918

The current y-splitter design are meant to be paired with original e3d with low profile pneumatic fitting instead of the chinese e3d v6 clone.

I added the new Y-splitter.stl based on the original prusa3d y-splitter. The one uploaded were to be used with 6mm diameter screw pneumatic fitting.

Currently the modded y-splitter still not tested yet as I have to print the MMU extruder again and fit them together.

MK2S Parts

I added the modified MK2S parts to fit several setups. Some of the parts has same postfix as the others; with and without "shorter" tag.

Also, added supports for inductive holder up to 12mm only and both 10mm has 2mm thicker base, 12mm has 4mm thicker base. This is to accommodate the bigger diameter of the inductive sensor types.

As for these, MK8 extruder type also uploaded and the screw requirement are still the same, check out "Between Normal and Shorter" section

See Probe Offset section for offset settings that were measured from the modeling software

Providing the original mk2s solid for modification by you guys as well.

Bowden will be coming soon

Between Normal and Shorter

just like in the above,

Shorter uses a minimum of M3x18 screw and you can use them on all 4 screw points.

Normal uses:
Based on MK2's assembly guide
1 x M3x25
1 x M3x18
1 x M3x30

Tested with the following screws on normal MK2 based:
2 x M3x25
2 x M3x20

M3x16 can be used only to fasten the extruder cover but there is a high chance that it will not reach the nut, using normal hex nut will fit on the slot as well.

Servo Types

These uses tower pro sg90 servo type or similar dimensions.

These is for those who're using servo for auto bed leveling systems like my printer yet wanted to have compact extruder set

Compatibility

This should be compatible with only either prusa mk2 or mk2s x-carriage due to different mounting screw hole width.

The carriage should be compatible with all or most prusa based structure out there. The x axis smooth rod distance are similar therefore the x-carriage should be compatible as well.

I found out that the original direct drive are not compatible with the most of the direct drive gears out there such as mk8 extruder or generic geared extruder. I searched the net that Prusa3d's extruder are 6mm in diameter while others are 7-11mm diameter. Info can be found here https://shop.prusa3d.com/forum/original-prusa-i3-mk2-f23/why-is-the-extruder-pulley-made-of-brass--t1105-s20.html#p20314

Probe Offset

MK2S 8mm - 23 x 9mm
MK2S 10mm - 25 x 10mm
MK2S 12mm - 25 x 11mm

BLtouch - 30.5 x 7mm

BLtouch offset is up to you if you want to use either 30 or 31mm and make sure you print about 2-6 BLTouch spacer

What to Print?

If you're wondering what to print, I will give you the basic idea

  • carriage.stl
  • extruder_cover.stl
  • mk2s based (any of your preferred extruder style and probe type, also short or long type).stl
  • mk2_mmbased(any of your preferred probe type also short or normal).stl if you're going for multi material
  • y-splitter at https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2583563
  • 3x bltouch_spacer.stl (if you're going to use bltouch)

You might want to consider the changeable parts as well https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2558425

MK3 Parts?

You might want to consider going here https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2742381 for mk3 based extruder.

remixed_from.title: Hanging Belt Hanger MK2 with dress belt + regular belt hooks

title: Hanging Belt Hanger vol.2.1 with dress belt + regular belt hooks

description.text:
the original idea came from Grantbaxter (https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2169097).
his basic model has some wonderfull features i wanted to improve.

this cloth-hanger is designed to hold multible belts (or even heavier cloth) and it has stylish holes (to save filament) in which you can hang jewelery, scarves, ties, various other accesoires or even clothes hangers.
the hook must be printed horizontally for best strenght and mounted afterwards, so it should hold some weight easily!! it is big enough to fit on a 32mm rod.

the design is be printer-friendly. so there are no difficult overhangs or bridging and no additional supports should be needed :-)

my design is based on two other hooks, found here on thingiverse:

Curtain hook - by meetar (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16843)

General purpose hook (larger) - by Bartth (www.thingiverse.com/thing:2039243)

[update#1 12.03.2017]
after a suggestion from Grantbaxter, i added a S-shaped hook, so now you can hand things to the oval holes below. i must admit, it isn't the most beautifull one, but it'll do the job.

if you made your own hanger, feel free to share your "make" :-)
happy printing!

Printer:

geeetech prusa i3 pro c

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2mm Layer hight

Infill:

10-20%

Notes:

dimensions of the holder:
x=75mm
y=75mm
z=94mm

infill 15-20%. more doesn't bring any more stability.
increase perimeters/top- and bottom-layers instead for a stronger print! maximum ~6 should be more than sufficient

the hook must be printed horizontal for greater strenght

Plastic weight: 39.76 g (0.09 lb)

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

25

I am looking into get a garden going this year and have been researching ways to be low impact, simple, and productive. A hive of bees is a nice addition. Since members of my family are allergic to bees, mason bees (Which don't sting) are the way for me to go.

I liked a number of the Mason Bee designs available, but as I have said before, the Pacific Northwest causes a few problems for anything out-of-doors. There are a also a few things that Mason bees need that weren't accommodated for in some designs.

The little overhang will keep the openings dryer and protect (to some degree) from birds that will not now be able to attack the hive while standing on top of it, and the small design will allow me to create a few hives and spread them out.

There are holes in the bottom to affix it to the top of a fence post, and on the back to affix it to a south facing wall (In my area).

The drawer design allows me to clean out parasites and remove the larva in late October to store them for the winter. Come next March, I will be able to put the larva out in the sun to hatch. The small lips and grooves are to reduce the ability for any parasite that may get in (And they always do) from getting from one hole to the next. That is a big problem with some home-made hives.

There are two versions of the drawers (Or trays). With and without grips. The drawers fit nice and tight, so if you want the grips, just print that file. No need for both.

As always, I love hearing feedback. Ideas for improvement are always welcome.

title: Box with hidden hinges and click lock

description.text:
The box is perfect for bolts and nuts or small things you are constantly searching where are they :) The box's hinges are placed inside a box. Hinges inside give you more room for boxes.

There are two versions pins. A tight one and loose one. So you can test out which one works best for you. A pin should be printed horizontally.

A cover has a simple lock mechanism. And you should hear a solid CLICK when you open or close a box. When the box is assembled you should first try to open and close for about 20 times to loosen up a bit. But I guess it really depends on plastic. A model in the pictures is made of PLA and it needed about 20 "clicks" to have a smooth opening feeling.

Please share comments and makes! And help me improve the Box with your suggestions.

Have fun!

description.text:
There are many designs for bottle based bird feeders but the majority use plastic soda/coke style bottles. I was looking for something a bit more refined and decided to create my own design for screw top wine bottles. The majority of screw tops are based on the Stelvin wine closure which appears to have an M30 thread or at least the M30 produced by Fusion 360 fits like a glove.

The design as a feeder part together with a top section. One top section has holes not parallel with the bottom. The two parts being intended to be linked using paracord or tent guy-rope cord. The other top section has holes aligned with the bottom so the two sections can be joined with threaded rod. The holes are 6mm.

As it would be a pain to dribble bird seed into the opening of a wine bottle, I've also included a screw-on funnel. Possibly overkill but the opening of our normal funnel would not allow the seed to flow properly.

The final STL of the feeder section is slightly different from the other images - I removed a domed section that was intended to spread the seed but just made it jam up. Also increased the areas joining the threaded section to the base.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

20 - 30%

Notes:

Feeder section 30% infill.
No supports.
3 Shells
3 Top and bottom layers.
1mm drainage holes are included but may require opening depending on the accuracy of your printer. A Dremel or small drill would be fine or possibly a heated needle.

Top section 20% infill.
Supports from print bed for the hole 'wings' only.

Funnel settings not that important but will need supports from print bed to the hole at the top of the threaded area.

3 shells and top/bottom layers.

I printed in HTPLA (because the silver looks quite cool) but ABS or PETG would be OK. Don't know how standard PLA would hold up being left outside for any length of time.

5-10W lighting/lamp for 3D printer with 30mm Alu frame. For example Rebel II and clones. Designed for right side, for left side just mirror model. Stl and Step model included. Plastic holder includes simple shade to prevent glare of operator.
BOM:
printed plastic holder (less then 58ccm plastic)
M6x12 (for example DIN 912) bolt + nut into alu profile
Aluminium heatsink (50x50x30mm) mine is from older AMD cooler (or chinese 50x50x11 with 5W)
5-10W 12V LCD array. (1-2E on aliexpress sold for car interier lightning includes 2pin connector )
2pin cable with 2,5mm connector connected o 12V source

If u have another 50mm heatsink just edit included step model.

Rebel ozmod

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

33% +

Notes:

Use ABS or material with similar temperature resistance. Better infill means stronger holder. but 33% and 2 outer lines are enough.

Assembling:

U need to use nut with Alu profile and bolt M6x12mm. Remeber to insert nut into profile before u fix printer frame otherwise its little bit tricky. Small hole in shadow is used for LCD eletric cable including connector. if u use screws for extra safe lcd fixing on coller u may need to little bit grind down first spur on coller guide grooves.
For 5W smaller array u can use 1,5$ heatsink from ali 50x50x11mm and apropriate 11mm holder model.
Remember 10W LCD is enough to iluminate small room for most people is 5W version more then enough.

title: Bend Spiral Bowl Advanced cnc/laser

description.text:
After the this feedback of my first Bend Spiral Bowl I started to research for an improvement that would make the built easier. It took me a darn whole day and several prototype to realize, that it couldn't be easier than this: after breaking the spiral arms several time I started to water the wood and heat it up in the microwave oven. As last time I used a suitable bowl to bend the arms into position. Now I discovered that you don't even need those brackets. When cooled and dried the arms stay in position and just a little drop of woodglue secures them completely.

My build was done on a desktop cnc-machine by Stepcraft from 6 mm birch plywood using a spiral-toothed 1.2 mm flute.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

Please be aware that you can download the design for free for personal use only. Do not commercially use my designs. As the images are for illustration here on Thingiverse, they are not part of the CC license. Please do not distribute the pictures!

Intructions

I wrote an Instructable on how to make these bowl.

remixed_from.title: OmniStand Mod Backside with Filamentguide for Flashforge Dreamer / Dremel Idea

description.text:
I have been using AspireMGF external spool holder for a while and came across the series of OmniStand designs. I like the OmniStand design because I can use the universal spool holders internally and the stand has locking clips to prevent from shifting off its mount, but I want to retain the flexibility of mounting the spool mount anywhere along the printer frame without screws.

I thought of just to do a quick mash of AspireMGF movable mount and PeterS1 external mount. The mashup fits nicely as per AspireMGF's original version, though it will not flex as much during the mounting because the OmniStand is thicker. Please note I printed the part in ABS, if you print in PLA it will (likely) be unable to snap the holder on to the frame because at this thickness PLA will hardly flex, and AspireMGF's holder is designed to fit snug against the printer frame.

IMPORTANT !!!
Please note this mashup is done directly in FlashPrint, hence the file extension must be changed to "fpp" before you can open it. I have no intention to do a STL for now as the mash prints nicely straight from FlashPrint and is designed specifically for the Flashforge Dreamer only. I also want to demonstrate how easy it is to do quick customising in a slicer with just the scale/move/cut functions.

Printer:

Flashforge Dreamer

No

This a fidget spinner for students to create and remix themselves to provide them a tool to keep their hands busy during lessons.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.3

Infill:

30%
Super glue the Bolt and Nut together to keep the pieces from falling apart.
CCSS
The students wanted to learn how to make a fidget spinner so they did not have to buy one. We came across a model and the students learned how to create moving pieces.

Step 1 - Create a circle with a box attached with a height of 5 and group them together.
Step 2 - Duplicate this shape two more times. Rotate these shapes to create a Y shape.
Step 3 - Create a hold cylinder in the middle of the object that is 12x12
Step 4 - Create a new object that is a cylinder that is 14x14x2, place a tube on top of this object that is 10x10x4. Group these together
Step 5 - Duplicate this shape and place another cylinder inside the duplicated shape's tube that is 7x7x8.
Step 6 - Remix how every you want.
picture of spinner , 3d printer, filament , nuts for weights for you would like to add them.

Step 1 - Create a hold cylinder in the middle of the object that is 12x12
Step 2 - Create a new object that is a cylinder that is 14x14x2, place a tube on top of this object that is 10x10x4. Group these together
Step 3 - Duplicate this shape and place another cylinder inside the duplicated shape's tube that is 7x7x8.

title: Improved Spool Holder for the Original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text:
If you have a Original Prusa i3 MK2 like mine you love it for sure, BUT (in my opinion) the spool holder is really not good at all, it is difficult to adjust and set up. So I've decided to create my own which can accomodate any type of spools and changhing filament can't be easier :-). In the folder you will download I've included some typical CAD format so if you like you can modify to your needs.

If you like you can whatch this video where I show how I did it: https://youtu.be/ehwsGeesCF0 (italian version)

P.S.: in the download file you will find the FEA Report so you can watch it and see all the stresses and the forces and how they act on the model and also a PDF with the dimensions of the spool holder

UPGRADED VERSION 3.0:
I have pubblished an upgrade to this design which is a bit bigger, but since it is optimized to be printed with 0.3 mm layer height instead of 0.2 mm the time it takes to print is not so much longer than before. By having it bigger I've managed to reduce significantly the deflection in the arm and by oprimizing the dimension to be printed with 0.3mm layer height is also noticebly sturdier than before.

P.S.: If you print one I will be delighted if you post a photo of your print on this page.
If you have any problem just write it in the comment and I'll try to figure it out :-)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.3 mm for the UPGRADED (3.0) version 0.2 mm for the OLDER (2.0) version

Infill:

not less than 20%

Notes:

With theese settings:

  • Print time: 4h
  • Filament lenght: 33615.7 mm or 33.6157 m
  • Plastic weight: 101.07g

NOTICE:
It is possible to print it with no support material what so ever since the overhang is very small, but that may result in a not great quality on the final part of the arm. If you choose to print it without support I reccomend to file down with some sand paper the rough part left by the printer where the overhang is. It doesn't have to be pretty since this is mostly a functional print.

PS: The stl file shuold be already positioning in order to minimaze the support material. My advice is to not change the orientation of the stl file once imported in the slicer.

I've designed it in Autodesk Fusion 360

I've gone throw some design changes but this it's really great because it is really optimized with a lot of FEA studies. Just to give you an idea i've applied 20N of force on the arm (2 times the force it has to overcome because a typical spool weights around 10N or 1Kg) and it was still showing a minimum safety factor of 11.38 so you can be absolutely sure that with 1 kg spool it will never break and it doesn't require a ton of plastic to print:-)

It's a really simple design with just 4 extrusion and a lot of fillets. In the zip file you will download you will find the CAD model so you can modify it if you like. Complete assembly in Fusion 360 Here you can see the stresses acting on the model. If you are interested check out the " Study_Report_Spool_holder_3.0_UPGRADED.html" in the files you will download for a complete FEA study Italian Version

comments.text:
ABS is the best material to print and PETG is great. I have printed it in PLA too and I haven't got any problem so far and it is almost a year since I have printed it and I haven't experienced any problem at all :-) PLA is not the best but from experience I know it works.
An advice I can give you if you want to print it il PLA is to be sure your printer is very giod at printing PLA and to use an high infill :-) 0.3 mm layer heihgt is a must ;-)
comments.author: amcolley

comments.text: The FEA analysis is meaningless without taking into account the shape that is actually printed, and the anisotropy present in prints - namely that the inter-layer shear strength is much lower than the intra-layer strength, and the strength along the filament is better than the strength between adjacent filament strands in a single layer. An actual gcode should be converted to a 3D anisotropy map and then applied to the nodal properties of the mesh. You may need a better FEA tool :)
comments.author: kmsd3d

comments.text: Yes you are absuolutely right I need a more powerfull software for the FEA of 3D printed parts but remeber that you always have to interpret the results of the tools you have. Now let's assume my 3D printed part is 4 time less strong than the model in CAD. The FEA showed e minimu safety factor of 11.38 now let's divide this nuber by 4 and we have a minimum safety factor af almost 3 which is more than accetpable. I'm sure about taht because I've just studied it in advanced FEA studies at the University :-). So that study is not that meaningless ;-)
comments.author: kmsd3d

comments.text: It's not meaningful to talk about a "3x less strong" material when the geometry of what you're analyzing doesn't match the geometry of the printed part and when there's anisotropy. Due to anisotropy and stress concentrations (e.g. at infill transitions), there can be areas where your printed part has 2 orders of magnitude lower strength for certain stresses. Of course that's a very conservative number, but it's not unusual to see parts where a print has areas that are 10-20x less strong than a solid isotropic plastic part made of the same material would be.

title: duck belt buckle (duckle)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple superior belt buckle to use with common fabric belts.

The prototype printed in PLA worked. Havent printed this refined version yet but I guess there won't be any surprises.

14.03.2017: latest version (schnoin16.stl) now rotated upside down to prevent ugly surface pointing upwards while wearing, it also comes with less edgy corners, a looser fit for the snappers, a tighter fit for the... umm... main-buckle-lever(?), a button-hole and +20% fancyness (still not sure if that faux-poly-art-stuff is better than none at all).

Pictures soon to come.

15.03.2017: Face it - ducks are great. We all love ducks. So there's a belt buckle with a duck on it now. Enjoy.

16.03.2017: Latest iteration features a more sturdy wall, sharper teeth, a more graceful shape, a shorter lever, some further minor improvements and a bent duck.

23.04.2017: A serious buckle for serious events (funerals, weddings and stuff) - with a checkered pattern instead of a ducky one. I printed that one in polycarbonate... it's actually much more transparent than the picture suggests; and the most sturdy so far I guess. However I haven't managed to destroy any other version yet. Even a (lay-)wooden one still works, although it's a bit loose by now.

10.11.2017: After about half a year in use, the PC buckle broke. Unexpectedly it was the bottom corner on the main-frame that got ripped off while the lid with it's thin cylindric parts stayed intact (I always thought that might be the weak spot). So I redesigned the whole thing for better stability and less thickness. Top and bottom faces now are thicker and the whole buckle is 2mm thinner. That's as slim and sturdy as it can get, I guess. I've also gotten rid of the actually useless hole in the wall and made the "teeth" more even. The current version is #49 and comes in an empty and in a duckish version again. The one in the picture was done in yellow PETG.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Works fine in PLA, looks great and works even better in green-tec. Guess almost any material is fine for that buckle, however it most likely makes sense to select something with good layer bonding and some reasonable amount of flexibility.

Should be printed in the given position with about 20% zig-zag infill, everywhere, for structures above 85° At least these settings work fine for me on cura. Nozzle size was 0,5mm for that one but I guess bigger ones will work even better.
Some sanding perhaps.

title: web clamp adapter for quick-change bar clamp and nylon strap

description.text: I went to Clas Ohlson to look for a web clamp, but the closest thing I could find was a squeeze-handle mini bar clamp with the Cocraft brand name (like most tools there). So I made adapters to hold some 15mm nylon webbing on the jaws, and now I have a web clamp. It works well, except that the clamping force is limited by those plastic squeeze handles on the clamp. Good for clamping round or irregularly shaped things while gluing. Probably it turns out that the same clamps are sold around the world with different brand names. It's customizable in case the dimensions of yours are different. The OpenSCAD code is modular enough that this would be a good starting point for anything else that you'd like to attach to your clamp jaws.

title: Maze Cylinder Box Visible or Hidden

description.text:
Another maze box.
Remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207662 a great maze and labyrinth box on thingiverse.
Features:
-Combined Visible and Hidden variants.
-Visible option so the maze is on the exterior of the inside cylinder
-Hidden option so the maze is on the interior of the outside cylinder, making it completely hidden until the entire maze is solved!
-Completely customizable in openscad. The maze is specified by an array. Box sizes and thicknesses are parameters that can be changed. The number of "maze nubs" can be changed.

You can download 1, 2 and 3 from https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207662
I have included maze model #4 STLs. cheer4ftc released the model in his comments.

Fixed issue with Hidden Maze too loose.

You can purchase other printed models from my online shop at
https://www.etsy.com/shop/3DFabXYZ
or visit my website http://3DFabXYZ.com/blog/

comments.text: Why post something that you wont share.
comments.author: Kardon1976

comments.text:
The file that you can download is an openSCAD file.
The way I see it, I have given you more than just a file you can print.
With the downloadable file you can easily modify it (with openSCAD) to create your own mazes.
The 3 included mazes are from the original 2 openSCAD scripts that I remixed from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207662.
I did not see the point of creating the printable models as they are the same as those from the original link and as I am a supporter of open source software, prefer that you get your prefab models from the original source (so that cheer4ftc gets recognized for his work).
All I have done is combine 2 scripts into one and made it available through the customizer thing app (link above).
I have posted my version of the script(s) so that others could see how I have combined the two.
If you are interested in creating your own models to share feel free to use openSCAD available at www.openscad.org and modify the script yourself.
I understand that you are new to the 3D printing world (as you have not shared any designs yourself or know what a *.scad file is).
In the future please take the time to understand what someone has provided you, rather than attempt to flame them.
If you would have just sent a private message, I might have taken the time to help you get started with openSCAD, then maybe you could have created something to share as I did.
Hope this has answered your question.
Powodzenia Kardon1976!

title: OpenWhoop Parametric Micro Racing Multirotor Drone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
OpenWhoop is my attempt at my own "TinyWhoop Like" design for off the shelf common parts.

My goal was to make something easily tunable/tweakable via parameters, so I could adjust/dial it in as I crash it and total the frame.

Also allowing others to tune it to their parts/needs

It's heavily inspired by the "Whoopie" at: https://oscarliang.com/whoopee-micro-frame/ but was designed from scratch in OpenSCAD.

I also originally wanted to make a hex with it, so that's designed in. However I struggled to get a hex to fit into my target 110mm wheelbase for the local indoor fpv racing club rules, so I had to drop it to a quad. So the library supports both options.

Lastly, I wanted to move the camera out in front, as I had an idea for an integrated single part print, without add-on parts that could support variable angles for the FPV camera, and keep it out in front to keep the rotors out of the view.

Designed in OpenSCAD so all you need to do is open the config file, edit the values to your desired parameters (note there are 2 configs, one for quad, one for hex) and then open the QuadFrame or HexFrame scad, render, and export to STL.

I printed this in PLA, and Result from the Quad, was a 14g frame all one piece which I added everything else to for an All Up Weight of about 56g before battery. (right now using a much too large battery at 800mah, picking up some smaller batteries to fly with). Even with the 800mah, it's pretty quick, and agile. Flies very well.

I included a default STL for both hex and quad. The Quad STL is the one I actually printed, and have flown, and is shown in the pic.

The Hex is designed to be smaller, using actual Inductrix props, but on 8.5mm motors (would likely require some persuasion to get the prop onto the slightly larger shaft). I suspect it would perform VERY well. But have yet to pick up the props to try it out.

The current build is using the following parts:

  • Hubsan H107d props
  • 8.5mm motor set from HobbyKing
  • Edge Brushed Naze32 Flight Controller from HobbyKing (supports hex brushed motors)
  • Latest BetaFlight 3.x on controller
  • Eachine micro cam/vtx in one
  • Turnigy RX (stripped of it's casing) TGY-IA6C I believe, for a Turnigy Evolution

Props were from Amazon
Cam/VTX is a standard design from Eachine. I got it at LFS, but should be easy to find.
Here are the HobbyKing Part Numbers:

  • Motors - 154000032-0
  • Flight Controller - 571000106-0
  • RX - 9114000063-0

Also using a random 800mah battery from LFS, plan on swapping down to a 300mah or lower to reduce weight significantly.

Anyway, this is a work in progress, it flies nice, but still needs some work. But I thought I'd release it so that others could try it out, and I could get some feedback/suggestions from the community to improve it.

So give it a shot, I'd love to hear your feedback!

See below in the custom section for more detailed instructions.

If you like the design, let me know, and if you ever need this (or anything else) printed, don't hesitate to check out my hub on 3D Hubs: https://www.3dhubs.com/service/glasswalker

Thanks for looking!

Printer Brand:

CEL

Printer:

CEL Robox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

200um

Infill:

Solid

Notes:

Printed upside down, in PLA, 200 micron, with support, but no raft.

Using a custom profile tweaked to allow more solid printing with thin walls (thinner extrusion width, with tuned flow rate etc). It prints fine otherwise, but I found this resulted in an improved part.

Used OpenSCAD to design a library capable of creating the various parts:

  • Camera holder
  • Rotor Ducts/Nacelle
  • Motor Holders
  • Main Frame structures

Then setup a couple options for a hex or quad, using a config file to parametrically define motor size, rotor diameter, duct profile settings, camera dimensions, and desired wheelbase of the craft. The library does the rest, and generates an airframe for you.

Build Instructions

Just basically print one of the STL files, only the Quad is tested so-far using the parts above. Or your own parts. Or you can open one of the configs, edit the file for your own dimensions/parts, and export the new STL from the appropriate Frame SCAD file.

To Print just print upside down, on 200 micron print size, with support set to 65 degrees. This will support the motor pods, but not put extra support elsewhere. I found setting it lower resulted in "spare" support where I didn't want it.

Make sure your printer can handle thin walls. Right now the thinnest wall I believe is 1mm but needs to do that "reliably"

Other tips/steps:

  • I used a couple layers of foam tape to adhere the FC to the top of the frame, and the RX to the bottom of the frame, with the antenna whips dangling behind the pods.
  • I also used an extra pair of zipties to hold the battery (left loose so that battery could be slid in and out)
  • For the FPV cam, slide the camera antenna into the notch provided, and then nestle the camera body into the slanted support "socket". This will hold it in place at the right angle. This should leave the button free to push for channel changes, and expose the LED display on the back for easy FPV channel selection.
  • I just used a zip-tie to hold the camera in, the support has 2 notches on the sides on the right angle for a zip-tie or an elastic to hold the camera in.
  • Place Zip Ties around the bottom of the motor holders, and tighten as much as possible. This will "clamp" the motor holders down on the motors, keeping the motors firmly in place. This also keeps the motor holder from softening from heat (PLA not so good at taking heat) from the motors during flight.
Config File Instructions

For customizing the config file, there are 2 files, one for Hex, one for Quad. Eventually I'll better unify this.

  • motor_diameter is pretty self explanatory
  • motor_clearance is the extra clearance to add to the motor holders around the motor. The motor should easily slide in, but be snug. (it will be tightened with zip-tie)
  • motor_height is the length of the motor. I set this 2mm longer than the actual motor, because then I could tuck the wires from the motor up into the slot and under the zip-tie, which resulted in protecting the wires, and the extra end of the motor holder plastic then acts as landing gear. You could also just cap it with some heat-shrink and use that for landing gear too.
  • motor_mount_gap Is the gap in the motor mount for tightening with a zip-tie, it's the "slit" which faces into the FC.
  • rotor_diameter The diameter of your actual prop
  • rotor_clearance The clearance to provide inside the duct for the prop (note this is not an increase in Radius, it's an increase in total Diameter)
  • rotor_pod_fin_count Number of fins/struts/stators to add to the rotor pod/nacelle. The default is 3, more would be more sturdy, but also impact airflow and weight more.
  • rotor_pod_fin_angle Angle of the stators/fins. This is set to hopefully be optimal to not block airflow, due to the "vortex" created from the rotor. You can adjust the angle to be positive/negative depending on the rotor direction. Default BetaFlight rotor directions are applied with negative angle. If your FC requires reverse rotor rotations, switch to positive number here.
  • rotor_pod_fin_height vertical height of the fins/stators, again more is stronger, but more airflow impact, and weight.
  • duct_flair Duct Flair and curve are 2 parameters I use to calculate the curvature of the intake in the duct. It's not actually spherical, it's an exponential curve. Hard to explain these, so just experiment to find numbers that get the curve profile you like.
  • duct_curve See Duct Flair for more details
  • quad_frame_wheelbase_size This applies to Quad only, and is the desired wheelbase of the quad (diagonal max shaft to shaft distance). I set this based on flying rules at my local club.
  • quad_frame_wheelbase_width For the quad, you can customize it's aspect ratio. Setting the wheelbase size, will always maintain that size, but by adjusting the width manually, you can make it more long/slim, or short,wide etc...
  • hex_frame_wheelbase_size For hex only. For the Hex frame, the wheelbase is "circular" so all pods at same distance. No aspect to customize. This sets the diameter of that "circle" (and respectively the max wheelbase)
  • wall_thickness - Thickness of walls of the duct, etc. Most parts base off of this.
  • motor_wall_thickness - The motor holder and fins/stators use this value instead. Allowed them to be separate so that you could customize strength/weight as you see fit.
  • frame_thickness - This is the Z thickness of the inner frame structure. Note setting this too thin with an aggressive camera angle may result in the camera holder not rendering correctly. (not to mention again, thickness = strength + weight)
  • cam_width - the width of the camera "body" (side to side)
  • cam_length - length (front to back) of the camera body
  • cam_angle - Angle the camera should be tilted at. Positive angle tilts the camera up. Used to set your FPV angle.
  • cam_ant_width - Width of the antenna wire. Used to set the gap/slot for the antenna to fit through
  • cam_loffset_quad - For the quad only, this sets how far forward the camera holder should sit from the center point of the frame. This is used to manually tune where the camera sits.
  • cam_loffset_hex - For hex only. Same as the quad version. Just different value for the hex.
  • $fs & $fa - These are standard OpenSCAD settings for Circle/Arc resolution. FS is size of an arc segment in mm, fa is angular size. These are used to set the "quality" of circles/arcs.

author: Glasswalker

title: +30mm Y-Axis Endstop Extension for Wanhao Duplicator i3 with 8x10 Glass Bed

description.text:
I had ordered a Borosilocate glass plate but it was warped (seems to be a common issue).
Found a 8x10" glass plate for $2.20 at HomeDepot and it was flat
http://www.homedepot.com/p/8-in-x-10-in-x-125-in-Clear-Glass-90810/202091040
That plate fits right between the bolts on the heat bed but sticks out a bit at the back, so why not print on that new space? ;-)

The corners on the glass plate are very sharp, sand them down with sand paper and clean the plate. To install the glass plate you need to place 1" squares of heat sink (https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B007PPEW52) on the plate. I put them on top of my stock builtak plate. Most likely your builtak is already warped or has bubbles, just try to not put the strips on any "high spots". One side of the heat sink is more sticky than the other, put that side on the builtak. Put hairspray on the glass plate, let it dry and then place the glass plate on top, align between the bolts left and right and align the front of the glass with the heat bed. The rear will stick out a lot.
Level your bed again, you might have to move the z-axis switch up a notch in the bracket.

This y-axis bracket moves the micro switch 10mm further to the back which will basically give you 10mm extra space in the front of the plate. There is another 20mm at the rear of the plate that can now be used.

I printed with 100% infill. Tap the holes with screws first, insert the microswitch before mounting it to the frame, then carefully test to make sure nothing hits when homing the Z axis, especially if you have custom belt tensioners.
Then change the "Y max length" setting in the EEPROM, I used octoprint (great tool!) with the EEPROM Repetier plugin. Position the Z-axis to 220mm, disable the steppers and check how much more free room you have before hitting the end stops. Then repeat at 225mm and finally 230mm. At 230mm I only have 1mm before hitting the end stop.
Update the printer settings in your slicer and do a test print with objects in the far corners.
Cura 2.4 has a 2mm "offset" as well so if you want to print to the edge you need to increase your size in cura http://3dprinting.stackexchange.com/questions/645/cura-not-allowing-full-print-area-to-used

Btw, printing on glass is awesome, the bottom of the printer are super smooth and the objects just pop off the plate once it has cooled down.

Still have to work on a couple of things:

  • lost a few mm on the left, might have to adjust the x-axis sensor or change firmware settings to start printing a few mm to the right. Maybe use the glass plate as a "nozzle wipe"?
  • the heatbed cable rubs on the glass plate, need a bracket to or rotate the heat bed 90 degree and use a cable chain.

comments.text: This looks like an awesome upgrade. Just wondering if you can do the same setting changes from the control box. I found a y Max of 200 in the configuration menu under feed rate is this the same setting? I tried it but my plate won't move past 200.

comments.text: no, that's different, you'll have to make the change in the EEPROM

description.text: This is a case for the Parallella embedded computer. It includes a mount for 40mm fan which can be mounted on the inside or outside of the case.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Infill:

50% or greater recommended

Notes:

The pieces of this case snap together. The walls are 3mm thick - which provides a solid case and stronger tabs (I found that 2mm thick or less had weaker tabs that could break easily).

You can mount the fan on the inside of the case and power it via the mounting hole next to the barrel power connector on the board. You will also need to solder a jumper on J15 to make that connection hot.

Note that the fan clearance is sufficient for the small stock heat sink that came with the older Parallella card. It may work with the new larger heat sinks, but I do not have one of those to test with.

title: Vogelhaus / birdhouse (Villa / mansion)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Deutsch:
Welch wunderschönes Vogelhaus! Das war es zumindest Mal, doch das Norddeutsche Wetter hat ihm ganz schön zugesetzt. Darum soll es nun gerettet bzw. ersetzt werden. Der Bauplan stammt aus einer Heimwerkerzeitschrift und ich versuche nun die einzelnen Bauteile in Fusion360 umzusetzen und auf die passenden Größen für das Druckbett aufzuteilen. Sobald es neue Dateien oder Fotos gibt, lade ich sie direkt hier hoch.
Das Vogelhaus wird später diese Maße haben: (BxTxH) 464x670x530mm

Anregungen, Verbessungsvorschläge und Tipps sind gern gesehen!

English (at least I tried to translate):
What a beautiful bird house! Well, there was a time it was, but the weather here in northern germany damaged it. Therefore it is to be saved or replaced. The building plan is from a home improvement magazine and I am now trying to implement the individual components in Fusion360 and to divide the appropriate sizes for the printbed. As soon as there are new files or photos, I upload them here.
The bird house will have these dimensions: (WxDxH) 464x670x530mm

suggestions for improvement and tips are welcome!

Printer:

Anet A6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20

Material

Deutsch:

  • muss wasserresistent sein
  • muss UV-beständig sein
  • darf sich bei Hitze nicht verformen
  • ABS?

English:

  • must be water resistant
  • must be UV-resistant
  • must not deform during heat
  • ABS?
Deutsch - Dateibezeichnungen

Die Dateien sind nach den entsprechenden Bauteilen nummeriert. Viele sind jedoch so groß, dass sie nicht komplett auf das Druckbett passen. Deswegen sind sie in mehrere Teile aufgeteilt (1v3, 2v3, 3v3). Die letzte Zahl gibt an wie oft genau dieses Teil benötigt wird.

English - Filenames

The files are numbered according to the corresponding components. However, many are so large that they do not fit completely on the printbed. Therefore, they are divided into several parts (1v3, 2v3, 3v3). The last number indicates how often this part is needed.

Das Dach könnte man noch optmieren. Momentan nur eine Kunststoffplatte. Das Geländer beim Einstieg mache ich gerade. Übrigens sind die Geländer im 1.OG wegkippbar. Da ich vorgesehen habe den Boden zur Reinigung herauszunehmen, war mir die Bodenleiste im Weg. Im Dachspeicher könnte man das Netzgerät für die Beleuchtung einbauen.
